questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Eye speculum

Explanation:

  • An eye speculum is a surgical instrument used to hold the eyelids apart during ophthalmic procedures. It ensures proper exposure of the eye, facilitating examination or surgery, like enucleation.

Eye speculum

Doyen’s speculum (Option B) used in Gynaecology

Universal retractor (Option A) and Mouth clamp (Option C) are used in Dentistry

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Neural crest cells

Explanation:

  • The corneal endothelium originates from neural crest cells, which migrate during embryogenesis to form the inner layer of the cornea.
  • Neural crest cells also contribute to other anterior segment structures, including the stroma and trabecular meshwork.

Corneal Development and Cellular Origins

  • Corneal development involves ectodermal-derived tissues.
  • Neural ectoderm-derived optic vesicles interact with cranial ectoderm → form presumptive corneal epithelium and ocular surface epithelia. (Option A ruled out)
  • Neural tube-ectoderm interactions generate neural crest cells, which are migratory and multipotent.
  • Neural crest cells migrate between the lens and corneal epithelium → form corneal endothelium and stromal keratocytes.
  • Trigeminal ganglion (from neural crest and ectodermal placodes) supplies sensory innervation to the corneal stroma and epithelium.

Mesoderm (Option C): The mesoderm is responsible for forming structures like muscles, blood vessels, and connective tissue in the body. It does not contribute to the corneal endothelium.

Surface ectoderm (Option D): The surface ectoderm forms the corneal epithelium, the outermost layer of the cornea, but not the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: Riya was found to have a height of more than the 95th percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her showing characteristic signs is provided below. What is the most common ocular complication expected in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Subluxation of lens

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of tall stature flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers in suggestive of Marfan's syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is commonly associated with mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes the connective protein fibrillin.

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Multisystem disorder with involvement of the connective tissues.

Clinical features:

Skeletal abnormalities:
  • Tall stature
  • Arachnodactyly
  • Chest wall abnormalities like pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum
  • Thumb sign( On folding thumb, it will protrude beyond the ulnar border of palm) or wrist sign is positive
  • Increased joint laxity

CVS abnormalities:
  • Aortic root dilation
  • Mitral insufficiencies
  • Arrhythmias

Eye abnormalities:
  • Ectopia lentis or subluxation of the lens of the eye (Option D)
  • Blindness

Pulmonary involvement:

  • Increased risk of pneumothorax

Diagnosis:

  • Marfan syndrome is clinically diagnosed using Ghent criteria

questions.text: Which of the following best defines blindness ?

choices.text: Visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye
Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction
Visual field less than 10 degrees from fixation in the better eye
Inability to perceive light in both eyes

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction

Visual acuity less than 6/60 in the better eye (Option A ruled out): This level of visual acuity (or 20/200 in feet) is often referred to as legal blindness in many countries, including the United States, and is a criterion for eligibility for certain services. However, the international definition of blindness is typically more severe.
 

Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye after best possible correction (Option B): This is the definition of blindness according to the World Health Organization (WHO) and is widely adopted for international comparison. 3/60 means a person can see at 3 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters. This is the best definition of blindness among the choices.
 

Visual field less than 10 degrees from fixation in the better eye (Option C ruled out): A restricted visual field can also define blindness, particularly "tunnel vision." The WHO definition of blindness includes "or corresponding visual field loss," which for blindness is typically a visual field of 10 degrees or less from fixation in the better eye. This is also a valid criterion for blindness.
 

Inability to perceive light in both eyes(Option C ruled out): This is known as "No Light Perception" (NLP) and represents total blindness. While this is indeed a form of blindness, it is the most severe form. The general definition of "blindness" encompasses a broader range of severe visual impairment where some light perception or very limited vision might still be present.
